user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_get_device_property:
```c
int metal_linux_get_device_property(struct metal_device *device,
				    const char *property_name,
				    void *output, int len)
{
	int fd = 0;
	int status = 0;
	const int flags = O_RDONLY;
	const int mode = S_IRUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IROTH;
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/of_node/%s",
			 ldev->sdev->path, property_name);
	fd = open(path, flags, mode);
	if (fd < 0)
		return -errno;
	if (read(fd, output, len) < 0) {
		status = -errno;
		close(fd);
		return status;
	}

	status = close(fd);
	return status < 0 ? -errno : 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_get_device_property:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragments. The function and structs use only standard C constructs and POSIX API calls (open/read/close, errno, snprintf). I found no occurrences of common compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, labels-as-values, or other GNU/C specific builtins in the shown code.

Note: a macro call appears (metal_container_of) in to_linux_device. Its use here is not by itself an extension; however, the macro definition (not provided) should be reviewed because container_of-style macros sometimes use the GNU typeof extension or other non-standard constructs. Since that macro's definition is not in the supplied snippets, I did not mark any code as suspicious based solely on the call. If you provide the macro and other related macros/headers, I can re-evaluate them for language extensions.
